The junior debate try-out, held
last Friday at twelve o'clock, was
unusually interesting. Until the decision was finally rendered by Dr.
French, it was impossible to predict
which of the contestants would
make the team, all of them doing
almost equally well. In opening the
contest, Dr. French said that he
would not judge the debaters by
the kind of argument they presented, but upon their delivery,
presence and power to form fluent
sentences. Mr. Hammond, Mr.
Chenoweth, Mr. Herman, Mr.
Lauchheimer and Mr. Nachlas spoke
on the affirmative of the question:
"Resolved, That Without Regard
to the Obligations of the HayPauncefote Treaty, the Tolls of the
Panama Canal Should be the Same
for the Merchant Vessels of all
Nations," and Mr. White, Mr.
Sutton and Mr. Simpson on the
negative. After the first round of
speeches had been made, Dr. French
called on different contestants to
give parts of their speeches over
again.
The team as finally chosen was:
S. D. White, A. L. Hammond, K.
Simpson and L. B. Chenoweth, alternate.
Dr. French asked for a few days
in which to decide on the advisership. In the next few days the
team will learn on which side of the
Canal question it will be.
A great amount of enthusiasm
was shown by the members of the
junior class when the decision was
announced. The whole junior class
seems determined to defeat the
seniors, and the team knows it will.
The senior team has the prestige of
having won last year, but then the
team which the present seniors defeated had won in its junior year.
The senior team will be selected
next Friday at one o'clock in the
assembly hall.

The annual organization massmeeting for the baseball team will
be held Thursday afternoon, January 30, at five o'clock, in the Trophy
Room of the cage. A very large
attendance is expected, as unusual
interest has been manifested in baseball ever since the announcement of
the ambitious tenative schedule at
the football blowout several weeks
ago. All students and alumni of
the University are cordially invited
to be present by the baseball management. Everyone who can possibly do so, should make it a point
to be on hand, as there is nothing
which helps more at an organization
meeting than the enthusiasm which
a large crowd always creates. From
present indications, there will be
standing room only in the Trophy
Room by the time the meeting is
underway.
Captain Ernest J. Pieper, of the
baseball team, will preside at the organization meeting. Short speeches
will be made by a number of well
known persons connected with the
baseball team and University athletics in general. Among the speakers will be Dr. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Mr. B. Howell Griswold,
Jr.; Mr. Douglas C. Turnbull,
Coach Eddie Hooper, and Manager
C. Leland Getz.
The first practice of the baseball
candidates will be held on Saturday, February 1, in the cage. Coach
Eddie Hooper is planning to start
things going at once, as the season
will begin very early, on account of
Easter occurring so early. For the
first few weeks, practice will be
held only several times a week, and
then as the time for the opening of
the season draws near the number
of practices a week will be increased, especially after the baseball
squad begin its outdoor work.
Nearly all the members of last
year's team are back at the University and the number of new candidates promises to be unusually large.
Coach Hooper should have plenty
of material from which to select a
very strong nine. Hopkins should
win the majority of its games in
spite of the fact that Princeton,
Pennsylvania, Navy, the University
of Virginia and a number of other
big nines have places on schedule.
Since the last announcement was
made, contracts have been signed
for the following games, in addition to those already definitely arranged:
Tuesday, March 25—University
of Pennsylvania, at Homewood.

T

Chess Tournament.

The chess tournament commenced
last Wednesday, with the following
entrants: Hammond, Nachlas, Karl
Melamet, Otto Melamet,Yokoyama,
Weber, Corner, Schaffer, Kuehn,
Davis and Chenoweth. The tournament is a round robin; that is, each
contestant must play all the others
one game. First, second and third
prizes will be given to the three
men who finish with the highest
scores. It is planned to have an informal blowout at the conclusion of
the tournament, at which time the
trophies will be awarded.

Arthur Rankin Padgett, A. B.
'07, become a member of the law
firm of Hill, Ross & Hill of this city.
Brooke G. Bird, ex-:09, is spending a month's vacation in Baltimore.
Mr. Bird is resident engineer of
the Ambursen Hydraulic Construction Company, which has been doing extensive work in Canada.
Alan McChesney, M. D. '12, has
been appointed assistant resident
physician at the Rockefeller Institute, New York. He will engage
in research work there for six
months, and then probably return
to Hopkins.
The Chief of the Bureau of Sanitary Engineering of the State Board
of Health, Robert B. Morse, A. B.
'o6, who has been giving expert
testimony in the Baltimore county
sewerage case, is in bed, owing to
a serious illness. It was thought at
first that Mr. Morse had incipient
typhoid fever; however, he has become much better and will be out
in a week.

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 27, 1913
A Suggestion.

As the season rolls round again
for the annual banquets of the
classes, it is not unnatural to expect in some form or other a manifestation of the old rivalry between
sophomores and freshmen. Of itself this rivalry has some things to
commend it: it solidifies a class and
brings the various members into
closer touch with one another; it
inculcates into the freshmen a respect for upperclass men, which can
be made to subserve many useful
purposes, and it satisfies that need
of a "custom" or "tradition," which
everyone seems to feel. There has
been a time in the history of the
University when lower class rivalry
was carried to a point where it became objectionable but of late
years it has kept well within the
bounds of reason and good sense.
Raids on banquet rooms and a general smash up of dishes and furniture have become a thing of the
past; underclass banquets are no
longer refused by first-rate hotels;
and manifestations of class spirit
have been confined to a few harmless cases of "kidnapping." Even
"kidnapping" has very seldom been
abused. Men have not generally
been captured and kept in confinement for several days, so as to cause
their absence from their University
duties-and to alarm their parents.
On the day of a banquet one or
two men have usually been carried
off, "imprisoned" during the afternoon, and released after the conclusion of the banquet. The captive
has generally enjoyed the adventure
involved in this experience as much
as have his captors.
It is to be hoped that this moderation will be manifested again this
year. In order to insure that it will
be, THE NEWS-LETTER suggests
that the presidents of the two lower
classes come to an understandinothat no "kidnappings" shall take

place before the day on which a banquet is to be held. There is another
matter which requires notice also.
Attempts have sometimes been made
to capture a man in one of the University buildings. These buildings
are occupied not only by freshmen
and sophomores, nor even by undergraduates, but also by postgraduate
students and members of the faculty. To the convenience of the
latter, some regard should be had,
and such an agreement as that suggested might very well be made to
provide that the University buildings should not be the scene of any
"kidnappings."
This is merely a suggestion. THE
NEWS-LETTER cannot see how either
of these provisions would diminish
the sport of "kidnapping." The
first is only a crystallization of
custom; the second merely spares
inconvenience to certain persons
who have a right to be considered
without reducing in any way the
likelihood of a man's being caught
if he is wanted. And yet the two
would go a long way toward making it certain that class rivalry this
year will be characterized as last
year and the year before by the
exercise of good judgment.

An Admirable Provision.

One admirable feature of the
Inter-Fraternity agreement has just
come to notice in the recent differ-,
ence between Alpha Delta Phi and
the other fraternities. The punishment which the agreement provides
for a fraternity found guilty of an
offence by the Inter-Fraternity
Board is nothing but publicity. The
verdict, then, has no other effect
than to bring to light all the facts
in the case; and any verdict which
should not be supported by these
facts would bear its worthlessness
on its face and could accomplish no
harm. This arrangement seems to
insure the permanence of the agreement; for if a fraternity feels that
a verdict against it is unsubstantiated, all it has to do is to publish a
statement of its case. It is not likely
therefore that the recent lamentable
disagreement will disturb in any
way the unity with which the various fraternities are co-operating
for their common interest.

Resolutions of Condolence.

Resolutions passed on the death
of H. F. Boatwright, '13, by the
Class of 1913 of the Medical School:
Resolved that, Whereas, on this
sixteenth day of January, 1913, our
friend and classmate, Hal Fullerton
Boatwright, has passed from our
midst, we, his fellow students, in
meeting assembled, desire to express our sorrow at his untimely
death.
He was a man of unswerving uprightness, warm friendship and of
earnest purpose in his work.
It has, therefore, been decided to
send an expression of our sympathy
to the family of the deceased, and
to publish a copy of these resolutions in the John Hopkins NEWSLETTER and in the Johns Hopkins
Alumni Magazine.

Dr. Ames to Lecture.

The Norman W. Harris lectures
at Northwestern University will be
given this year by Dr. Joseph Sweetman Ames, professor of physics and
director of the physical laboratory
at Johns Hopkins University. Dr.
Ames will speak on "The Constitution of Matter," the individual subjects being as follows:
"General Properties of Matter;
Mass."
"Corpuscles and Atoms; Electrical Mass."
"Radioactivity; Gravitation."
"Radiation; Formation of Molecules; Elasticity."
"Properties of Metals; Thermionics."
"Models of Atoms; Conclusion."
The lectures will be given in the
week of February 25 to March 1,
in the Annie May Swift Hall at
Northwestern University.—Chicago
Post, January to, 1913.

THE NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 27, 1913.

THE FRATERNITY SITUATION
Statement of the Inter-Fraternity Board.

The Inter-Fraternity Board of
the Johns Hopkins University hereby notifies the students of the University that the. Alpha Delta Phi
Fraternity of the Johns Hopkins
University has violated Section 8 of
the In
Agreement by
. giving an intimation to a candidate
of their willingness to receive hint
as a memb.er of their Chapter.
By order of
•THE INTER-FRATERNITY BOARD.
Early in the year of 1912 delegates from the six fraternities at
Johns Hopkins met for the purpose
of forming some agreement by
means of which fraternity conditions at that College might be improved. Realizing that in order for
such an agreement to be of any
strength, there must be some penalty attached to an infringement of
the same, these delegates debated
for a long time as to what form
this penalty should take, and finally
decided that to publish the names
-of both the individual and the fraternity breaking the rules, in THE
NEWS-LETTER, 011 the McCoy Hall
bulletin board, and in the semi-annual announcement which the InterFraternity Board sends to the preparatory schools of Baltimore city
and vicinity, would be the penalty
best suited to fraternity conditions
at Hopkins. Fearing, however, that
when it had appeared that a violation of the agreement had occurred
the Inter-Fraternity Board might
be too hasty in coming to a decision,
it was agreed •that a, week must
elapse between the presentation of
the charges and the trial of the fraternity against which charges were
made. Moreover, realizing also
that it would be much better to have
a guilty fraternity escape than to
punish an innocent one, the delegates decided that to obtain a conviction, a unanimous vote should be
necessary (the fraternity on trial
having of course no vote). The
inter-fraternity agreement containing the points above mentioned was
signed by the delegates of each of
the six fraternities at Johns Hopkins on June II,. 1912.
On January To, 1913, charges
were brought against the Johns
Hopkins Chapter of the Alpha Delta
Phi Fraternity. After the lapse of
a week the trial was held at 5
P. M.,on Friday, January 17, in the
Trophy Room. Each witness„ was
summoned singly, his testiMony
heard; and then the right of questioning him was allowed every
member of the Board (of course
including the two members of the
Board representing the Alpha Delta
Phi Fraternity). Then the two
representatives of the accused fraternity presented their side of the
case, each member of the Board was
then given the opportunity of bringing out any points that had impressed him, either in favor of or
against the fraternity charged with
having broken the agreement, and

then the members of that fraternity
were asked if, before a vote was
taken, they had any further statement to make.' When every member of the Board had said all he desired, the chairman granted an intermission of five minutes, during
which each member of the Board.
consulted with the other representatives of his fraternity as to which
way the fraternity should vote, as
the vote in all meetings of the InterFraternity Board is taken according
to fraternities. During this intermission the chairman was asked
whether, in case the Alpha Delta
Phi Fraternity were declared guilty,
it would be necessary to have a
unanimous vote in fixing the penalty, and the chairman interpreted
the rules as making, in such a case,
a unanimous vote necessary. The
secretary called the roll and a delegate from each of the five fraternities sitting in judgment answered
"guilty" as the name of their fraternity was called.
A motion was now made that the
offending fraternity should not suffer the extreme penalty in that that
part of the penalty which has to do
with the semi-annual announcement
to the preparatory schools should
be omitted, but that the rest of the
penalty stipulated in the agreement
should be imposed on the Alpha
Delta Phi Fraternify. To this motion were now presented and passed
amendments to omit the name of
the individual breaking the agreement, and to send letters to the student whom it was shown had received an intimation from the Alpha
Delta Phi Fraternity of their willingness to receive him as a member
of their chapter, to the student's
father, and to the alumnus of the
fraternity through whom this intimation had come. It was then
moved and passed to lay the original motion on the table until the
following Monday, in order that
each member of the Board might
have more time to think the matter
over, and might thus refrain from
a too hasty decision as to the proper
penalty.
On Monday at 5 P. M., January
20, the Inter-Fraternity Board was
called to order, and it was moved
and passed to take off the table the
motion made on Friday concerning
the penalty. Here again each member of the Board had the freedom
of the floor and the right to state
his opinion as to what the penalty
should be. After this discussion had
closed, a vote was taken in the same
form as had been observed in the
trial, and the motion over which the
Board hadithad three days to consider, was unanimously passed.

Therefore, the notice which has
recently appeared on the McCoy
Hall bulletin board, and which now
appears at the head of this article,
was authorized by the Inter-Fraternity Board.

"Extemporaneous Speaking," by
Paul M. Pearson and Philip M.
Hicks. Hinds, Noble & Eldridge,
New York city. ($1.25.)
Of late years there has been
growing up a school of public speakers whose aim is not to invest their
subject with the pomp and dignity
of old fashioned oratory, but to approach their audience in as direct,
easy and intimate a way as they
can, and get as quickly as possible
to the plain facts of the case. This
is the ideal which underlies Professor Pearson's little volume. His
purpose is to show the student how
to talk as intelligently and convincingly on a subject which he knows
something about. The new speaking is not merely useful to the lawyer, the preacher, and the statesman, as was the old, but offers an
intensely valuable tool to the salesman, the engineer, and the business man—to every one in fact who
comes into contact with other persons and has to communicate with
them by means of language.
The book is divided into two
parts—a general discussion of the
principles of extemporaneous speaking and a selection of illustrative
speeches. These speeches are on
such topics as "The Principles of
Business Success," "The Railway
Rate Bill,""Vanadium Steels,""The
Honor System," "The Bible and
Progress," and are by President
Eliot, Senator La Folette, Governor
Wilson, President Taft and other
speakers of the same kind. There
is an appendix presenting within
the compass of a page the requirements of a good speech, another
suggesting subjects for speeches,
and a third giving hints to teachers
for the conduct of a public speaking
con rse.

"Propertius, a Modern Lover in
the Augustan Age," was the title
of a lecture by Prof. Kirby Flower
Smith, before the Classical Club of
Princeton University, on Friday
evening, January 17.
While the lecture was before the
Classical Club, the doors were
thrown open to the public, and it
is estimated that 300 persons heard
Professor Smith.
In Princeton, Professor Smith
was the guest of Prof. W. Sherwood Fox, of the classical department, who took his Ph.D. at Johns
Hopkins. He was entertained by
Professor Clapps.

The junior debate try-out, held
last Friday at twelve o'clock, was
unusually interesting. Until the decision was finally rendered by Dr.
French, it was impossible to predict
which of the contestants would
make the team, all of them doing
almost equally well. In opening the
contest, Dr. French said that he
would not judge the debaters by
the kind of argument they presented, but upon their delivery,
presence and power to form fluent
sentences. Mr. Hammond, Mr.
Chenoweth, Mr. Herman, Mr.
Lauchheimer and Mr. Nachlas spoke
on the affirmative of the question:
"Resolved, That Without Regard
to the Obligations of the HayPauncefote Treaty, the Tolls of the
Panama Canal Should be the Same
for the Merchant Vessels of all
Nations," and Mr. White, Mr.
Sutton and Mr. Simpson on the
negative. After the first round of
speeches had been made, Dr. French
called on different contestants to
give parts of their speeches over
again.
The team as finally chosen was:
S. D. White, A. L. Hammond, K.
Simpson and L. B. Chenoweth, alternate.
Dr. French asked for a few days
in which to decide on the advisership. In the next few days the
team will learn on which side of the
Canal question it will be.
A great amount of enthusiasm
was shown by the members of the
junior class when the decision was
announced. The whole junior class
seems determined to defeat the
seniors, and the team knows it will.
The senior team has the prestige of
having won last year, but then the
team which the present seniors defeated had won in its junior year.
The senior team will be selected
next Friday at one o'clock in the
assembly hall.

The annual organization massmeeting for the baseball team will
be held Thursday afternoon, January 30, at five o'clock, in the Trophy
Room of the cage. A very large
attendance is expected, as unusual
interest has been manifested in baseball ever since the announcement of
the ambitious tenative schedule at
the football blowout several weeks
ago. All students and alumni of
the University are cordially invited
to be present by the baseball management. Everyone who can possibly do so, should make it a point
to be on hand, as there is nothing
which helps more at an organization
meeting than the enthusiasm which
a large crowd always creates. From
present indications, there will be
standing room only in the Trophy
Room by the time the meeting is
underway.
Captain Ernest J. Pieper, of the
baseball team, will preside at the organization meeting. Short speeches
will be made by a number of well
known persons connected with the
baseball team and University athletics in general. Among the speakers will be Dr. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Mr. B. Howell Griswold,
Jr.; Mr. Douglas C. Turnbull,
Coach Eddie Hooper, and Manager
C. Leland Getz.
The first practice of the baseball
candidates will be held on Saturday, February 1, in the cage. Coach
Eddie Hooper is planning to start
things going at once, as the season
will begin very early, on account of
Easter occurring so early. For the
first few weeks, practice will be
held only several times a week, and
then as the time for the opening of
the season draws near the number
of practices a week will be increased, especially after the baseball
squad begin its outdoor work.
Nearly all the members of last
year's team are back at the University and the number of new candidates promises to be unusually large.
Coach Hooper should have plenty
of material from which to select a
very strong nine. Hopkins should
win the majority of its games in
spite of the fact that Princeton,
Pennsylvania, Navy, the University
of Virginia and a number of other
big nines have places on schedule.
Since the last announcement was
made, contracts have been signed
for the following games, in addition to those already definitely arranged:
Tuesday, March 25—University
of Pennsylvania, at Homewood.

T

Chess Tournament.

The chess tournament commenced
last Wednesday, with the following
entrants: Hammond, Nachlas, Karl
Melamet, Otto Melamet,Yokoyama,
Weber, Corner, Schaffer, Kuehn,
Davis and Chenoweth. The tournament is a round robin; that is, each
contestant must play all the others
one game. First, second and third
prizes will be given to the three
men who finish with the highest
scores. It is planned to have an informal blowout at the conclusion of
the tournament, at which time the
trophies will be awarded.

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 27, 1913
A Suggestion.

As the season rolls round again
for the annual banquets of the
classes, it is not unnatural to expect in some form or other a manifestation of the old rivalry between
sophomores and freshmen. Of itself this rivalry has some things to
commend it: it solidifies a class and
brings the various members into
closer touch with one another; it
inculcates into the freshmen a respect for upperclass men, which can
be made to subserve many useful
purposes, and it satisfies that need
of a "custom" or "tradition," which
everyone seems to feel. There has
been a time in the history of the
University when lower class rivalry
was carried to a point where it became objectionable but of late
years it has kept well within the
bounds of reason and good sense.
Raids on banquet rooms and a general smash up of dishes and furniture have become a thing of the
past; underclass banquets are no
longer refused by first-rate hotels;
and manifestations of class spirit
have been confined to a few harmless cases of "kidnapping." Even
"kidnapping" has very seldom been
abused. Men have not generally
been captured and kept in confinement for several days, so as to cause
their absence from their University
duties-and to alarm their parents.
On the day of a banquet one or
two men have usually been carried
off, "imprisoned" during the afternoon, and released after the conclusion of the banquet. The captive
has generally enjoyed the adventure
involved in this experience as much
as have his captors.
It is to be hoped that this moderation will be manifested again this
year. In order to insure that it will
be, THE NEWS-LETTER suggests
that the presidents of the two lower
classes come to an understandinothat no "kidnappings" shall take

place before the day on which a banquet is to be held. There is another
matter which requires notice also.
Attempts have sometimes been made
to capture a man in one of the University buildings. These buildings
are occupied not only by freshmen
and sophomores, nor even by undergraduates, but also by postgraduate
students and members of the faculty. To the convenience of the
latter, some regard should be had,
and such an agreement as that suggested might very well be made to
provide that the University buildings should not be the scene of any
"kidnappings."
This is merely a suggestion. THE
NEWS-LETTER cannot see how either
of these provisions would diminish
the sport of "kidnapping." The
first is only a crystallization of
custom; the second merely spares
inconvenience to certain persons
who have a right to be considered
without reducing in any way the
likelihood of a man's being caught
if he is wanted. And yet the two
would go a long way toward making it certain that class rivalry this
year will be characterized as last
year and the year before by the
exercise of good judgment.

An Admirable Provision.

One admirable feature of the
Inter-Fraternity agreement has just
come to notice in the recent differ-,
ence between Alpha Delta Phi and
the other fraternities. The punishment which the agreement provides
for a fraternity found guilty of an
offence by the Inter-Fraternity
Board is nothing but publicity. The
verdict, then, has no other effect
than to bring to light all the facts
in the case; and any verdict which
should not be supported by these
facts would bear its worthlessness
on its face and could accomplish no
harm. This arrangement seems to
insure the permanence of the agreement; for if a fraternity feels that
a verdict against it is unsubstantiated, all it has to do is to publish a
statement of its case. It is not likely
therefore that the recent lamentable
disagreement will disturb in any
way the unity with which the various fraternities are co-operating
for their common interest.

Resolutions of Condolence.

Resolutions passed on the death
of H. F. Boatwright, '13, by the
Class of 1913 of the Medical School:
Resolved that, Whereas, on this
sixteenth day of January, 1913, our
friend and classmate, Hal Fullerton
Boatwright, has passed from our
midst, we, his fellow students, in
meeting assembled, desire to express our sorrow at his untimely
death.
He was a man of unswerving uprightness, warm friendship and of
earnest purpose in his work.
It has, therefore, been decided to
send an expression of our sympathy
to the family of the deceased, and
to publish a copy of these resolutions in the John Hopkins NEWSLETTER and in the Johns Hopkins
Alumni Magazine.

Dr. Ames to Lecture.

The Norman W. Harris lectures
at Northwestern University will be
given this year by Dr. Joseph Sweetman Ames, professor of physics and
director of the physical laboratory
at Johns Hopkins University. Dr.
Ames will speak on "The Constitution of Matter," the individual subjects being as follows:
"General Properties of Matter;
Mass."
"Corpuscles and Atoms; Electrical Mass."
"Radioactivity; Gravitation."
"Radiation; Formation of Molecules; Elasticity."
"Properties of Metals; Thermionics."
"Models of Atoms; Conclusion."
The lectures will be given in the
week of February 25 to March 1,
in the Annie May Swift Hall at
Northwestern University.—Chicago
Post, January to, 1913.

Statement of the Inter-Fraternity Board.

The Inter-Fraternity Board of
the Johns Hopkins University hereby notifies the students of the University that the. Alpha Delta Phi
Fraternity of the Johns Hopkins
University has violated Section 8 of
the In
Agreement by

Early in the year of 1912 delegates from the six fraternities at
Johns Hopkins met for the purpose
of forming some agreement by
means of which fraternity conditions at that College might be improved. Realizing that in order for
such an agreement to be of any
strength, there must be some penalty attached to an infringement of
the same, these delegates debated
for a long time as to what form
this penalty should take, and finally
decided that to publish the names
-of both the individual and the fraternity breaking the rules, in THE
NEWS-LETTER, 011 the McCoy Hall
bulletin board, and in the semi-annual announcement which the InterFraternity Board sends to the preparatory schools of Baltimore city
and vicinity, would be the penalty
best suited to fraternity conditions
at Hopkins. Fearing, however, that
when it had appeared that a violation of the agreement had occurred
the Inter-Fraternity Board might
be too hasty in coming to a decision,
it was agreed •that a, week must
elapse between the presentation of
the charges and the trial of the fraternity against which charges were
made. Moreover, realizing also
that it would be much better to have
a guilty fraternity escape than to
punish an innocent one, the delegates decided that to obtain a conviction, a unanimous vote should be
necessary (the fraternity on trial
having of course no vote). The
inter-fraternity agreement containing the points above mentioned was
signed by the delegates of each of
the six fraternities at Johns Hopkins on June II,. 1912.
On January To, 1913, charges
were brought against the Johns
Hopkins Chapter of the Alpha Delta
Phi Fraternity. After the lapse of
a week the trial was held at 5
P. M.,on Friday, January 17, in the
Trophy Room. Each witness„ was
summoned singly, his testiMony
heard; and then the right of questioning him was allowed every
member of the Board (of course
including the two members of the
Board representing the Alpha Delta
Phi Fraternity). Then the two
representatives of the accused fraternity presented their side of the
case, each member of the Board was
then given the opportunity of bringing out any points that had impressed him, either in favor of or
against the fraternity charged with
having broken the agreement, and

then the members of that fraternity
were asked if, before a vote was
taken, they had any further statement to make.' When every member of the Board had said all he desired, the chairman granted an intermission of five minutes, during
which each member of the Board.
consulted with the other representatives of his fraternity as to which
way the fraternity should vote, as
the vote in all meetings of the InterFraternity Board is taken according
to fraternities. During this intermission the chairman was asked
whether, in case the Alpha Delta
Phi Fraternity were declared guilty,
it would be necessary to have a
unanimous vote in fixing the penalty, and the chairman interpreted
the rules as making, in such a case,
a unanimous vote necessary. The
secretary called the roll and a delegate from each of the five fraternities sitting in judgment answered
"guilty" as the name of their fraternity was called.
A motion was now made that the
offending fraternity should not suffer the extreme penalty in that that
part of the penalty which has to do
with the semi-annual announcement
to the preparatory schools should
be omitted, but that the rest of the
penalty stipulated in the agreement
should be imposed on the Alpha
Delta Phi Fraternify. To this motion were now presented and passed
amendments to omit the name of
the individual breaking the agreement, and to send letters to the student whom it was shown had received an intimation from the Alpha
Delta Phi Fraternity of their willingness to receive him as a member
of their chapter, to the student's
father, and to the alumnus of the
fraternity through whom this intimation had come. It was then
moved and passed to lay the original motion on the table until the
following Monday, in order that
each member of the Board might
have more time to think the matter
over, and might thus refrain from
a too hasty decision as to the proper
penalty.
On Monday at 5 P. M., January
20, the Inter-Fraternity Board was
called to order, and it was moved
and passed to take off the table the
motion made on Friday concerning
the penalty. Here again each member of the Board had the freedom
of the floor and the right to state
his opinion as to what the penalty
should be. After this discussion had
closed, a vote was taken in the same
form as had been observed in the
trial, and the motion over which the
Board hadithad three days to consider, was unanimously passed.

Therefore, the notice which has
recently appeared on the McCoy
Hall bulletin board, and which now
appears at the head of this article,
was authorized by the Inter-Fraternity Board.

GYM TEAMS PICKED

"Extemporaneous Speaking," by
Paul M. Pearson and Philip M.
Hicks. Hinds, Noble & Eldridge,
New York city. ($1.25.)
Of late years there has been
growing up a school of public speakers whose aim is not to invest their
subject with the pomp and dignity
of old fashioned oratory, but to approach their audience in as direct,
easy and intimate a way as they
can, and get as quickly as possible
to the plain facts of the case. This
is the ideal which underlies Professor Pearson's little volume. His
purpose is to show the student how
to talk as intelligently and convincingly on a subject which he knows
something about. The new speaking is not merely useful to the lawyer, the preacher, and the statesman, as was the old, but offers an
intensely valuable tool to the salesman, the engineer, and the business man—to every one in fact who
comes into contact with other persons and has to communicate with
them by means of language.
The book is divided into two
parts—a general discussion of the
principles of extemporaneous speaking and a selection of illustrative
speeches. These speeches are on
such topics as "The Principles of
Business Success," "The Railway
Rate Bill,""Vanadium Steels,""The
Honor System," "The Bible and
Progress," and are by President
Eliot, Senator La Folette, Governor
Wilson, President Taft and other
speakers of the same kind. There
is an appendix presenting within
the compass of a page the requirements of a good speech, another
suggesting subjects for speeches,
and a third giving hints to teachers
for the conduct of a public speaking
con rse.

Professor Smith Lectures.

"Propertius, a Modern Lover in
the Augustan Age," was the title
of a lecture by Prof. Kirby Flower
Smith, before the Classical Club of
Princeton University, on Friday
evening, January 17.
While the lecture was before the
Classical Club, the doors were
thrown open to the public, and it
is estimated that 300 persons heard
Professor Smith.
In Princeton, Professor Smith
was the guest of Prof. W. Sherwood Fox, of the classical department, who took his Ph.D. at Johns
Hopkins. He was entertained by
Professor Clapps.
